rev.diff:
Line 65: Line 65:
===2009 alleged internal governmental dissent===
===2009 alleged internal governmental dissent===
According to a [[WikiLeaks]] report released 31 January 2011, in December 2009 [[United States]] diplomat Angie Bryan claimed that there had been opposition to Saleh from his closest advisors for several months. Bryan wrote, "Like other Saleh watchers, xxxxx<ref name="why_xxxxx">Names hidden by [[WikiLeaks]] and [[United States diplomatic cables leak|collaborating newspapers]].</ref> characterizes the multitude of threats facing Saleh as qualitatively different and more threatening to the regime's stability than those during any other time in Yemen's history. 'Saleh is overwhelmed, exhausted by the war, and more and more intolerant of internal criticism. Saudi involvement comes at just the right time for him' xxxxx said. Largely unprecedented criticism of Saleh's leadership within the rarified circle of Saleh's closest advisors has increased in recent months, even including longtime Saleh loyalists such as Office of the Presidency aides xxxxx, according to xxxxx. These names add to the growing chorus of Saleh loyalists that have shed their traditional aversion to disparaging the man they call 'The Boss'".<ref name="09SANAA2279">{{cite document| last = Bryan | first =Angie| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Yemeni tribal leader: for Saleh, Saudi involvement in Sa'ada comes not a moment too soon | id={{WikiLeaks cable|09SANAA2279}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-12-28| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/12/09SANAA2279.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8OrQ284 |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
According to a [[WikiLeaks]] report released 31 January 2011, in December 2009 [[United States]] diplomat Angie Bryan claimed that there had been opposition to Saleh from his closest advisors for several months. Bryan wrote, "Like other Saleh watchers, xxxxx<ref name="why_xxxxx">Names hidden by [[WikiLeaks]] and [[United States diplomatic cables leak|collaborating newspapers]].</ref> characterizes the multitude of threats facing Saleh as qualitatively different and more threatening to the regime's stability than those during any other time in Yemen's history. 'Saleh is overwhelmed, exhausted by the war, and more and more intolerant of internal criticism. Saudi involvement comes at just the right time for him' xxxxx said. Largely unprecedented criticism of Saleh's leadership within the rarified circle of Saleh's closest advisors has increased in recent months, even including longtime Saleh loyalists such as Office of the Presidency aides xxxxx, according to xxxxx. These names add to the growing chorus of Saleh loyalists that have shed their traditional aversion to disparaging the man they call 'The Boss'".<ref name="09SANAA2279">{{cite document| last = Bryan | first =Angie| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Yemeni tribal leader: for Saleh, Saudi involvement in Sa'ada comes not a moment too soon | id={{WikiLeaks cable|09SANAA2279}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-12-28| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/12/09SANAA2279.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8OrQ284 |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
â
===Arrests and repression===
  â
[[File:Yemen protest3.jpg|thumb|A television reporter in the middle of protesters in Sana'a on 3 February.]]
  â   â
On 23 January, Tawakel Karman was detained and charged with "'inciting disorder and chaos' and organising unauthorised demonstrations and marches".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Authorities release journalists for fear of Tunisia-style unrest | work =| publisher =[[International Freedom of Expression eXchange|IFEX]] | date =2011-01-26| url =http://www.ifex.org/yemen/2011/01/26/karman_released/ |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-01 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wBItIgt2 |archivedate=2011-02-01 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Karman was a leader of two student rallies in Sana'a and called for the overthrow of Saleh's regime.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained"/> Her husband said her whereabouts were not known.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Several hundred students protested outside [[Sanaa University]] demanding her release.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Thousands of people protested against the arrest of Karman and other protestors by a sit-in outside of the prosecutor's office. She was freed 30 hours after her arrest on parole, with the condition not to violate "public order and the law".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" /> Karman returned to participating in demonstrations hours after her release.<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" />
  â   â
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of 20 people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sanaa a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen deports foreign journalists |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html |newspaper= |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php |title=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests - Committee to Protect Journalists |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
 
==Protest timeline==
==Protest timeline==
Line 390: Line 384:
===Tactics===
===Tactics===
Students and [[human rights in Yemen|human rights activists]] disagree with [[Political parties in Yemen|political parties]] regarding tactics for political change in Yemen. Some political parties are calling for reform to take place under President Saleh, while students and human rights activists wish to "channel the momentum of the [[2010â2011 Arab world protests|uprisings in the region]]."<ref name="WP_Yemeni_tactics" /> In late January, a lawyer and human rights activist involved in organising protests, Khaled al-Anesi, stated "There is a popular movement and a political movement in Yemen. But there is no support from the political parties for the popular movement, which is not organised. It is still weak and in the beginning stages."<ref name="WP_Yemeni_tactics">{{cite news | first=Sudarsan | last=Raghavan | pages= | language =| title=In Yemen, calls for revolution but many hurdles (page 1) | date=2011-01-30 | publisher=Washington Post | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/30/AR2011013003175.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8L4BScB |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}, {{cite news | first=Sudarsan | last=Raghavan | pages= | language =| title=In Yemen, calls for revolution but many hurdles (page 2) | date=2011-01-30 | publisher=Washington Post | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/30/AR2011013003175_2.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8L34I7R |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Students and [[human rights in Yemen|human rights activists]] disagree with [[Political parties in Yemen|political parties]] regarding tactics for political change in Yemen. Some political parties are calling for reform to take place under President Saleh, while students and human rights activists wish to "channel the momentum of the [[2010â2011 Arab world protests|uprisings in the region]]."<ref name="WP_Yemeni_tactics" /> In late January, a lawyer and human rights activist involved in organising protests, Khaled al-Anesi, stated "There is a popular movement and a political movement in Yemen. But there is no support from the political parties for the popular movement, which is not organised. It is still weak and in the beginning stages."<ref name="WP_Yemeni_tactics">{{cite news | first=Sudarsan | last=Raghavan | pages= | language =| title=In Yemen, calls for revolution but many hurdles (page 1) | date=2011-01-30 | publisher=Washington Post | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/30/AR2011013003175.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8L4BScB |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}, {{cite news | first=Sudarsan | last=Raghavan | pages= | language =| title=In Yemen, calls for revolution but many hurdles (page 2) | date=2011-01-30 | publisher=Washington Post | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/30/AR2011013003175_2.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8L34I7R |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
  +   +
===Arrests and repression===
  +
[[File:Yemen protest3.jpg|thumb|A television reporter in the middle of protesters in Sana'a on 3 February.]]
  +   +
On 23 January, Tawakel Karman was detained and charged with "'inciting disorder and chaos' and organising unauthorised demonstrations and marches".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Authorities release journalists for fear of Tunisia-style unrest | work =| publisher =[[International Freedom of Expression eXchange|IFEX]] | date =2011-01-26| url =http://www.ifex.org/yemen/2011/01/26/karman_released/ |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-01 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wBItIgt2 |archivedate=2011-02-01 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Karman was a leader of two student rallies in Sana'a and called for the overthrow of Saleh's regime.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained"/> Her husband said her whereabouts were not known.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Several hundred students protested outside [[Sanaa University]] demanding her release.<ref name="aljaz_karman_detained" /> Thousands of people protested against the arrest of Karman and other protestors by a sit-in outside of the prosecutor's office. She was freed 30 hours after her arrest on parole, with the condition not to violate "public order and the law".<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" /> Karman returned to participating in demonstrations hours after her release.<ref name="ifex_karman_freed" />
  +   +
On 14 March, security forces raided an apartment shared by four Western journalists and deported them. [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the action and noted that two other foreign journalists were also deported two days earlier. The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] also condemned the expulsions. They also said that two Yemeni journalists informed them that a group of 20 people, believed to be government supporters, went to the Journalists Syndicate in Sanaa a day earlier{{When|date=March 2011}} and threatened to burn it down.<ref name="AJYemen15Mar">{{cite news |title=Yemen deports foreign journalists |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314212132903514.html |newspaper= |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> They further said that Yemeni journalists are facing increasing harassment.<ref>{{cite web|author=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests |url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/attacks-on-journalists-in-yemen-sudan-amid-street.php |title=Attacks on journalists in Yemen, Sudan amid street protests - Committee to Protect Journalists |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
